channel.title: Is Linux really better for home users than XP?
channel.description: I am just some kid who uses XP in his room (I don't have a server or anything), so would I benefit from switching to Linux? My computer is MORE than capable of running XP, so it is not a performance issue.

item.title: Is Linux really better for home users than XP?
item.dc:creator: @Rictoo Rictoo
item.description:
@Rictoo wrote:

I have installed and uninstalled Linux SEVEN times, and each time I hated it

Read full topic

I am just some kid who uses XP in his room (I don't have a server or anything), so would I benefit from switching to Linux? My computer is MORE than capable of running XP, so it is not a performance issue.

Also, using Linus requires some Knowhow. XP is made for your avergae computer user

I use kubuntu 6.06 if anyone is interested

but if you want to try something new you can like get VMware or a old PC to try linux and start learning etc.

item.title: Is Linux really better for home users than XP?
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

If you have no reason for switching then it is a little pointless. If you used your computer as a server or something then yeah it would be a god idea, but there are a lot of programs you wont be able to run in Linux, not even with an emulator.

Read full topic

item.source: Is Linux really better for home users than XP?

item.title: Is Linux really better for home users than XP?
item.dc:creator: @Zach1188 Zach1188
item.description:
@Zach1188 wrote:

Ron:

[quote author=Zach1188 link=topic=4826.msg48882#msg48882 date=1150496014]
I am just some kid who uses XP in his room (I don't have a server or anything), so would I benefit from switching to Linux? My computer is MORE than capable of running XP, so it is not a performance issue.

Partition your harddrive and give half to XP and half to Linux. You can create a dual boot system. Every time you reboot, it will ask you, Windows or Linux. So then you won't have to give up xp for a differnet operating system. :)[/quote]
Yeah, thats what I did with Kubuntu a while back. Right now I am only using XP (One partition). Should I install Kubuntu again?

Read full topic
item.source: Is Linux really better for home users than XP?

item.title: Is Linux really better for home users than XP?
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

Zach1188:

I am just some kid who uses XP in his room (I don't have a server or anything), so would I benefit from switching to Linux? My computer is MORE than capable of running XP, so it is not a performance issue.

Partition your harddrive and give half to XP and half to Linux. You can create a dual boot system. Every time you reboot, it will ask you, Windows or Linux. So then you won't have to give up xp for a differnet operating system.

Read full topic
item.source: Is Linux really better for home users than XP?

item.title: Is Linux really better for home users than XP?
item.dc:creator: @Xerxes Xerxes
item.description:
@Xerxes wrote:

I think you should stick with XP. If you have no problems with it and feel secured. And use common sense. I am using XP to do all the normal stuff. I sugegst you to stay with XP or whatever, but if you want to try something new you can like get VMware or a old PC to try linux and start learning etc.

Read full topic
item.source: Is Linux really better for home users than XP?
